sections.description: SuiteCommerce Advanced style is focused on a minimalist use of simple elements, typography and flat colors. This allows the design to be more streamlined and efficient. Making it easier to convey information while still looking visually appealing and approachable. With minimal design, elements are able to load faster and resize easily and still look sharp on high-definition screens. Additionally, elements can be responsive to different browsers across different devices.

Here you will find the main user interface color palette for the out of the box theme. Shades of orange, blue-grey, white and grey are used for backgrounds, boders, buttons and text all along the application.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-primary
modifiers.description: The Primary Color is used for primary actions and highlighted information.

sections.markup: sc-color-primary
sections.css: $sc-color-primary: #e23200;
sections.renderMarkup: sc-color-primary

modifiers.name: $sc-color-secondary
modifiers.description: The Secondary Color is used for secondary actions. Different shades of this color are used for theme backgrounds, borders and text.

sections.markup: sc-color-secondary
sections.css: $sc-color-secondary: #15607b;
sections.renderMarkup: sc-color-secondary

sections.description: The neutral shade palette is a scale from 1000 (dark) to 0 (light). This theme defines a couple of medium scale values. The developer might find useful to add more intermetiate colors within the scale that might be referenced to this scale.

modifiers.name: $sc-neutral-shade-900
modifiers.description: The darkest value on this scale is raraly used. It may be found on some texts or backgrounds.

modifiers.name: $sc-neutral-shade-600
modifiers.description: In occasions you will find this shade assigned to text but most of the times it will be the shade used for shadows.

modifiers.name: $sc-neutral-shade-300
modifiers.description: This light shade is used exclusively used in texts.

modifiers.name: $sc-neutral-shade-0
modifiers.description: The lightest value on this scale is largely used and may be usually found in texts, backgrounds and borders.

sc-neutral-shade-900
sc-neutral-shade-600
sc-neutral-shade-300
sc-neutral-shade-0
sections.renderMarkup:
sc-neutral-shade-900
sc-neutral-shade-600
sc-neutral-shade-300
sc-neutral-shade-0

sections.description: Just as the neutral shades palette, the Theme Palette is a scale from 1000 (dark) to 0 (light). This theme defines a couple of medium scale values. The developer might find useful to add more intermetiate colors within the scale that might be referenced to this scale.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-theme-900
modifiers.description: Used mainly for headings

modifiers.name: $sc-color-theme-400
modifiers.description: Used mainly for general backgrounds (also referenced as $sc-color-theme-background)

modifiers.name: $sc-color-theme-300
modifiers.description: Used mainly for borders (also referenced as $sc-color-theme-border-light)

modifiers.name: $sc-color-theme-200
modifiers.description: Used mainly for borders (also referenced as $sc-color-theme-border)

sections.description: The message box is defined by a colored text displayed over a colored background with an outline border. It might or may not include an icon in which case it should use the same color as the text. Possible message types are: Success, Warning, Error and Information. Each type is defined by a main color used for text. Background and border colors are calculated according to the main color.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-success, $sc-color-success-background, $sc-color-success-border
modifiers.description: Used for success messages.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-warning, $sc-color-warning-background, $sc-color-warning-border
modifiers.description: Used for warning messages.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-error, $sc-color-error-background, $sc-color-error-border
modifiers.description: Used for error messages.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-info, $sc-color-info-background, $sc-color-info-border
modifiers.description: Used for information messages.

sections.description: Links are used primarily as a navigational element. Links may also change what or how data is displayed (view more, show all). If the action taken by the user will change or manipulate data, use a button. Two different color variables are defined for this element:

modifiers.name: $sc-color-link
modifiers.description: The color the link is written with. This color should ensure they look clickable.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-link-hover
modifiers.description: The color with which links are hilighted when hovered.

sections.markup:
sc-color-link
sc-color-link-hover
sections.css:
$sc-color-link: #0067b9;
$sc-color-link-hover: desaturate(lighten($sc-color-link, 15), 15);
sections.renderMarkup:
sc-color-link
sc-color-link-hover

sections.description: The out of the box theme uses only 3 different color shades when it comes to rendering text. The shades available are:

modifiers.name: $sc-color-copy-dark
modifiers.description: Used for almost every text on the site.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-copy
modifiers.description: Mainly used for values such as SKU

modifiers.name: $sc-color-copy-light
modifiers.description: Used for labels

sc-color-copy-light

sections.description: A scale of sizes has been defined for its use along the different elements of the theme. As it happens with many other sizing scales variables go from XS to XXXL Every size is relative to a base font size that may be modified. In that case all the other sizes will change in relationship to this new base size. With the exception of this base font size expressed in pixels, font sizes are expressed in rem units.

sections.description: Atoms are the abstract basic building blocks of matter. Applied to web interfaces, atoms are the HTML tags, such as a form label, an input or a button. They can’t be broken down any further.

Buttons are tools that enable users to perform a task. Some tasks are more important than others, and creating effective buttons with the right combination of size, color, position and wording is required. Good design can subconsciously communicate priority to users. Using the right combination of these components buttons will guide the user through the tasks required to achieve the main purpose or use case of a website.
sections.css: @import "atoms/buttons.scss";

sections.description: The primary action is generally the action that completes a task or desired action. Primary buttons use bright and use saturated colors to provide stronger visual weight that catches the users attention to avoid confusion and competing with secondary actions.
sections.markup: <button class="button-primary button-medium">Button Primary</button>
sections.renderMarkup: <button class="button-primary button-medium">Button Primary</button>

sections.description: A secondary action is not as important as a primary action. You should give secondary buttons less visual weight than primary actions. Less saturated colors are used on secondary buttons resulting in distinguishable buttons that don't stand out as much as primary buttons.
sections.markup: <button class="button-secondary button-medium">Button Secondary</button>
sections.renderMarkup: <button class="button-secondary button-medium">Button Secondary</button>

sections.description: Tertiary buttons are either not related to the main task, or the least desired actions. Visually tertiary buttons blend in to the interface background avoiding to distract the user from their primary task.
sections.markup: <button class="button-tertiary button-medium">Button Tertiary</button>
sections.renderMarkup: <button class="button-tertiary button-medium">Button Tertiary</button>

sections.markup: <button class="button-link">Button link</button>
sections.renderMarkup: <button class="button-link">Button link</button>

sections.description: There are three button sizes, which can be combined with Primary, Secondary and Tertiary buttons to create different hierarchies.

sections.description: Push buttons are used to open push panels that appear in smaller screens which hide information from the user until they request for it. Push buttons have a chevron indicating that the user is navigating somewhere rather than performing an action. Push buttons have a title and sometimes hint information related to the information in the push panel.
Push buttons can contain hint information related to what is inside the push panel. This might help the user understand what sort of information to expect when pressing the button.

Split buttons are used when multiple actions can be performed. The most relevant or common action a user can perform is placed on the button while other actions are placed inside a dropdown menu. There are two actionable areas on a split button, the primary action and the dropdown menu. Each has their own independent hover and focus status. Split buttons can be combined with any of the available button sizes.

sections.description: Pills are a series of buttons grouped together on a single line. Button groups are used for buttons that control the view of an area and only one of them can be selected at a time. Make sure to provide visual contrast to the active button.

sections.description: Copy refers to the text that appears within a user interface. Users rarely read every word on a page. Thus, creating visual hierarchy is essential for users to understand the information. It also impacts how users scan a website. To make copy scannable you should provide good contrast between the different elements. This creates different focus points and guides the user through the content. For example, highlighting links and bolding important information creates scannable focus-points. Poor contrast results in users getting lost in the content and causes them to scan more slowly.

sections.description: Web forms establish or enhance a relationship between the user and the organization. They establish a dialogue and, therefore, represent a two way communication between two parties. Form elements enable this communication.
sections.css: @import "atoms/forms.scss";

sections.description: Clear labels let the user know which data is being requested in each field. An optimal placement of labels would be above the input. This helps the user to scan through the form and increase completion rate. Labels also serve to distinguish between input fields that are required vs those that are optional.
Text fields are the most common type of fields on forms. They enable the user to enter data.

Select menus are used when multiple pre-populated options are available for the user to select. Use select menus when you have more than 3 options for users to select from otherwise use radio buttons.
sections.markup:
<label for="sample-select">Sample select:</label>
<select name="sample-select">
  <option selected disabled>choose one</option>
  <option value="1">1</option>
  <option value="2">2</option>
  <option value="3">3</option>
</select>
<label for="sample-select">Sample select disabled:</label>
<select name="sample-select" disabled>
  <option selected disabled>choose one</option>
  <option value="1">1</option>
  <option value="2">2</option>
  <option value="3">3</option>
</select>
sections.renderMarkup:
<label for="sample-select">Sample select:</label>
<select name="sample-select">

  <option value="2">2</option>
  <option value="3">3</option>
</select>
<label for="sample-select">Sample select disabled:</label>
<select name="sample-select" disabled>
  <option selected disabled>choose one</option>
  <option value="1">1</option>
  <option value="2">2</option>
  <option value="3">3</option>
</select>

sections.description: Text areas are used for multi-line input fields, typically used if the user needs to enter larger data like explanations or messages.
sections.markup: <textarea>Textarea</textarea>
sections.renderMarkup: <textarea>Textarea</textarea>

sections.description: A group of Check boxes are used when multiple choices are possible within a list of options. Selecting one option does not deselect the others. Use a stand-alone check box if there is a single option that the user can turn on or off. Both label and box are tappable, making it easier for the user to check the box.
Radio buttons are used when there are a few options to select from and only one selection is allowed. With radio buttons options remain visible and easier to scan.
If an input returns an error while validating, a wide red border is applied to make it visible and stand out from other input elements. A brief error message is also displayed below.
Use brief and concise help text only when needed. Help text is placed below the field since it's optional for the user to read it. Avoid long help text accompanying the form.
sections.markup:
<label>Sample field:</label>
<input type="text"  />
<small class="help-text"> Help text always must be defined after input.</small>

sections.description: Use tool-tips for longer descriptions that the user can click on when they need help for that field.

When users are interacting with an application they often expect feedback. This feedback can have different tones or communicate different types of information. For example, the application may display confirmation messages if a form is submitted successfully or error message if there were problems.

sections.description: Molecules are the smallest fundamental units of compound made up of two or more atoms held together to form a simple piece of functionality. They are simple combinations built to reuse, but not necessarily have meaning on their own without further context. Molecules often serve as the backbone for a more complex system.
Expanders are used to show users a snippet of a larger body of text in order to keep the user interface lightweight and easy to scan. Content is revealed when requested by the user.

sections.description: A flyout is a contextual popup that is used to temporarily show details related to what the user is currently doing. Flyouts can be used to show options or controls in response to a user tap or click. A flyout is always dismissed when the user taps outside of it or re-taps on the element that triggered the flyout.

sections.description:
Carousels are used to display multiple pieces of content in a single, noticeable space. In our implementation, this organism is used in different ways:

  • To display interactive banners for example, Home Page
  • To display images of a product for example, Product Details
  • To display a list of products for example, Merchandizing Zone

It's required call to BxSlider plugin in order to build the gallery. To do that, you have to execute from the Backbone.View the following; Utils.initBxSlider($('[data-slider]'), [options]).

Information cards are blocks of content that group related pieces of information. Cards have meaning by themselves, independently to where they are being displayed. For example, an address is composed of related pieces of information that grouped together have meaning regardless of where it is being displayed.

sections.description:
A push pane is used for presenting complementary information within the context of a page. Push panes are used specifically in small screen devices. This type of pane is always triggered by the user when a push button is tapped. Push panes slide from right to left using a push animation.

It's not required HTML markup to build a Push Pane, this component has to be invoked from a Backbone.View. To do that, it's necesary execute "this.application.getLayout().showInPush(view)", where "view" parameter is the content which you want to show.

Some of the molecules listed on this styleguide are responsive and change their behaviour according to the device or browser width. This is one of those, so, you might change the width of your browser window and see the molecule change its behaviour.

Dates have many possible representations varying by culture and personal preference. Providing a visual representation of dates, in a familiar calendar format, facilitates entering dates in a consistent format. The Date picker is used by the user either to select a date or to filter by a range of dates. In cases where it is available, system native pickers are preferred since they are familiar to the user. For cases in which there is no native date picker available, SuiteCommerce Advanced relies on the bootstrap-datepicker component.

It's required include 'bootstrap-datepicker' library in your Backbone.View.

section.description: SuiteCommerce Advanced style is focused on a minimalist use of simple elements, typography and flat colors. This allows the design to be more streamlined and efficient. Making it easier to convey information while still looking visually appealing and approachable. With minimal design, elements are able to load faster and resize easily and still look sharp on high-definition screens. Additionally, elements can be responsive to different browsers across different devices.

Here you will find the main user interface color palette for the out of the box theme. Shades of orange, blue-grey, white and grey are used for backgrounds, boders, buttons and text all along the application.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-primary
modifiers.description: The Primary Color is used for primary actions and highlighted information.

section.markup: sc-color-primary
section.css: $sc-color-primary: #e23200;
section.renderMarkup: sc-color-primary

modifiers.name: $sc-color-secondary
modifiers.description: The Secondary Color is used for secondary actions. Different shades of this color are used for theme backgrounds, borders and text.

section.markup: sc-color-secondary
section.css: $sc-color-secondary: #15607b;
section.renderMarkup: sc-color-secondary

section.description: The neutral shade palette is a scale from 1000 (dark) to 0 (light). This theme defines a couple of medium scale values. The developer might find useful to add more intermetiate colors within the scale that might be referenced to this scale.

modifiers.name: $sc-neutral-shade-900
modifiers.description: The darkest value on this scale is raraly used. It may be found on some texts or backgrounds.

modifiers.name: $sc-neutral-shade-600
modifiers.description: In occasions you will find this shade assigned to text but most of the times it will be the shade used for shadows.

modifiers.name: $sc-neutral-shade-300
modifiers.description: This light shade is used exclusively used in texts.

modifiers.name: $sc-neutral-shade-0
modifiers.description: The lightest value on this scale is largely used and may be usually found in texts, backgrounds and borders.

section.description: The message box is defined by a colored text displayed over a colored background with an outline border. It might or may not include an icon in which case it should use the same color as the text. Possible message types are: Success, Warning, Error and Information. Each type is defined by a main color used for text. Background and border colors are calculated according to the main color.

modifiers.description: Used for error messages.

modifiers.description: Used for information messages.

section.description: Links are used primarily as a navigational element. Links may also change what or how data is displayed (view more, show all). If the action taken by the user will change or manipulate data, use a button. Two different color variables are defined for this element:

modifiers.name: $sc-color-link
modifiers.description: The color the link is written with. This color should ensure they look clickable.

modifiers.name: $sc-color-link-hover
modifiers.description: The color with which links are hilighted when hovered.

section.markup:
sc-color-link
sc-color-link-hover
section.css:
$sc-color-link: #0067b9;
$sc-color-link-hover: desaturate(lighten($sc-color-link, 15), 15);
section.renderMarkup:
sc-color-link
sc-color-link-hover

section.description: A scale of sizes has been defined for its use along the different elements of the theme. As it happens with many other sizing scales variables go from XS to XXXL Every size is relative to a base font size that may be modified. In that case all the other sizes will change in relationship to this new base size. With the exception of this base font size expressed in pixels, font sizes are expressed in rem units.

section.description: Atoms are the abstract basic building blocks of matter. Applied to web interfaces, atoms are the HTML tags, such as a form label, an input or a button. They can’t be broken down any further.

Buttons are tools that enable users to perform a task. Some tasks are more important than others, and creating effective buttons with the right combination of size, color, position and wording is required. Good design can subconsciously communicate priority to users. Using the right combination of these components buttons will guide the user through the tasks required to achieve the main purpose or use case of a website.
section.css: @import "atoms/buttons.scss";

section.description: The primary action is generally the action that completes a task or desired action. Primary buttons use bright and use saturated colors to provide stronger visual weight that catches the users attention to avoid confusion and competing with secondary actions.
section.markup: <button class="button-primary button-medium">Button Primary</button>
section.renderMarkup: <button class="button-primary button-medium">Button Primary</button>

section.description: A secondary action is not as important as a primary action. You should give secondary buttons less visual weight than primary actions. Less saturated colors are used on secondary buttons resulting in distinguishable buttons that don't stand out as much as primary buttons.
section.markup: <button class="button-secondary button-medium">Button Secondary</button>
section.renderMarkup: <button class="button-secondary button-medium">Button Secondary</button>

section.description: Tertiary buttons are either not related to the main task, or the least desired actions. Visually tertiary buttons blend in to the interface background avoiding to distract the user from their primary task.
section.markup: <button class="button-tertiary button-medium">Button Tertiary</button>
section.renderMarkup: <button class="button-tertiary button-medium">Button Tertiary</button>

section.markup: <button class="button-link">Button link</button>
section.renderMarkup: <button class="button-link">Button link</button>

section.description: There are three button sizes, which can be combined with Primary, Secondary and Tertiary buttons to create different hierarchies.

modifiers.name: .button-small

section.description: Push buttons are used to open push panels that appear in smaller screens which hide information from the user until they request for it. Push buttons have a chevron indicating that the user is navigating somewhere rather than performing an action. Push buttons have a title and sometimes hint information related to the information in the push panel.
Push buttons can contain hint information related to what is inside the push panel. This might help the user understand what sort of information to expect when pressing the button.

Split buttons are used when multiple actions can be performed. The most relevant or common action a user can perform is placed on the button while other actions are placed inside a dropdown menu. There are two actionable areas on a split button, the primary action and the dropdown menu. Each has their own independent hover and focus status. Split buttons can be combined with any of the available button sizes.

section.description: Pills are a series of buttons grouped together on a single line. Button groups are used for buttons that control the view of an area and only one of them can be selected at a time. Make sure to provide visual contrast to the active button.

section.description: Copy refers to the text that appears within a user interface. Users rarely read every word on a page. Thus, creating visual hierarchy is essential for users to understand the information. It also impacts how users scan a website. To make copy scannable you should provide good contrast between the different elements. This creates different focus points and guides the user through the content. For example, highlighting links and bolding important information creates scannable focus-points. Poor contrast results in users getting lost in the content and causes them to scan more slowly.

section.description: Web forms establish or enhance a relationship between the user and the organization. They establish a dialogue and, therefore, represent a two way communication between two parties. Form elements enable this communication.
section.css: @import "atoms/forms.scss";

section.description: Clear labels let the user know which data is being requested in each field. An optimal placement of labels would be above the input. This helps the user to scan through the form and increase completion rate. Labels also serve to distinguish between input fields that are required vs those that are optional.
Text fields are the most common type of fields on forms. They enable the user to enter data.

Select menus are used when multiple pre-populated options are available for the user to select. Use select menus when you have more than 3 options for users to select from otherwise use radio buttons.
section.markup:
<label for="sample-select">Sample select:</label>
<select name="sample-select">
  <option selected disabled>choose one</option>
  <option value="1">1</option>
  <option value="2">2</option>
  <option value="3">3</option>
</select>
<label for="sample-select">Sample select disabled:</label>
<select name="sample-select" disabled>
  <option selected disabled>choose one</option>
  <option value="1">1</option>
  <option value="2">2</option>
  <option value="3">3</option>
</select>
section.renderMarkup:
<label for="sample-select">Sample select:</label>

  <option value="3">3</option>
</select>
<label for="sample-select">Sample select disabled:</label>

  <option selected disabled>choose one</option>
  <option value="1">1</option>
  <option value="2">2</option>
  <option value="3">3</option>
</select>

section.description: Text areas are used for multi-line input fields, typically used if the user needs to enter larger data like explanations or messages.
section.markup: <textarea>Textarea</textarea>
section.renderMarkup: <textarea>Textarea</textarea>

section.description: A group of Check boxes are used when multiple choices are possible within a list of options. Selecting one option does not deselect the others. Use a stand-alone check box if there is a single option that the user can turn on or off. Both label and box are tappable, making it easier for the user to check the box.
Radio buttons are used when there are a few options to select from and only one selection is allowed. With radio buttons options remain visible and easier to scan.
If an input returns an error while validating, a wide red border is applied to make it visible and stand out from other input elements. A brief error message is also displayed below.
Use brief and concise help text only when needed. Help text is placed below the field since it's optional for the user to read it. Avoid long help text accompanying the form.
section.markup:
<label>Sample field:</label>
<input type="text"  />
<small class="help-text"> Help text always must be defined after input.</small>

For example, the application may display confirmation messages if a form is submitted successfully or error message if there were problems.

section.description: Molecules are the smallest fundamental units of compound made up of two or more atoms held together to form a simple piece of functionality. They are simple combinations built to reuse, but not necessarily have meaning on their own without further context. Molecules often serve as the backbone for a more complex system.
Expanders are used to show users a snippet of a larger body of text in order to keep the user interface lightweight and easy to scan. Content is revealed when requested by the user.

section.description: A flyout is a contextual popup that is used to temporarily show details related to what the user is currently doing. Flyouts can be used to show options or controls in response to a user tap or click. A flyout is always dismissed when the user taps outside of it or re-taps on the element that triggered the flyout.

section.description:
Carousels are used to display multiple pieces of content in a single, noticeable space. In our implementation, this organism is used in different ways:

  • To display interactive banners for example, Home Page
  • To display images of a product for example, Product Details
  • To display a list of products for example, Merchandizing Zone

It's required call to BxSlider plugin in order to build the gallery. To do that, you have to execute from the Backbone.View the following; Utils.initBxSlider($('[data-slider]'), [options]).

Information cards are blocks of content that group related pieces of information. Cards have meaning by themselves, independently to where they are being displayed. For example, an address is composed of related pieces of information that grouped together have meaning regardless of where it is being displayed.

section.description:
A push pane is used for presenting complementary information within the context of a page. Push panes are used specifically in small screen devices. This type of pane is always triggered by the user when a push button is tapped. Push panes slide from right to left using a push animation.

It's not required HTML markup to build a Push Pane, this component has to be invoked from a Backbone.View. To do that, it's necesary execute "this.application.getLayout().showInPush(view)", where "view" parameter is the content which you want to show.

Some of the molecules listed on this styleguide are responsive and change their behaviour according to the device or browser width. This is one of those, so, you might change the width of your browser window and see the molecule change its behaviour.

Dates have many possible representations varying by culture and personal preference. Providing a visual representation of dates, in a familiar calendar format, facilitates entering dates in a consistent format. The Date picker is used by the user either to select a date or to filter by a range of dates. In cases where it is available, system native pickers are preferred since they are familiar to the user. For cases in which there is no native date picker available, SuiteCommerce Advanced relies on the bootstrap-datepicker component.

It's required include 'bootstrap-datepicker' library in your Backbone.View.
